Award.AwardTitle: The Visible Spectral Properties of Trojans and NEOs
Award.AbstractNarration: The Trojan asteroids orbit the Sun in a 1:1 resonance with Jupiter, centered on, and librating around, that planet's L4 and L5 Lagrange points. Originally thought to have been captured form the outer parts of the asteroid belt, the Trojans are proposed in newer theories to have been captured from the Kuiper belt during a period of extreme mixing of the small bodies of the Solar System. In-depth study of these objects provides constraints on the degree of dynamical mixing in the early Solar System as well as on the compositions of primitive bodies. In this project, the Principal Investigator and collaborators will use ground-based telescopes in Arizona and South Africa to make visible and near-infrared spectrophotometric observations of hundreds of Trojan asteroids as well as dozens of near-Earth objects (NEOs), obtaining taxonomic classifications and spectral slopes. Determining the relative fractions of the dominant taxonomic classes at different sizes of Trojans will constrain dynamical mixing implied by the "Nice Model" of the early Solar System. By combining new and archival data, the team hopes also to determine whether the different spectral types seen are related by "space weathering" processes or actually reflect compositional differences. The NEO observations will complement other ongoing observational programs and are designed to aid in the timely characterization of potentially hazardous objects and possible space mission targets.

Performance_Institution.Name: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used telescopes in Arizona and South Africa to study nearly 200 small bodies in Jupiter's orbit and beyond. We focused on the Trojan asteroids, which orbit the Sun at the distance of Jupiter. These objects are of great interest to planetary scientists because research in the past decade indicates that they likely formed at the edge of the Solar System beyond Neptune and were perturbed into their current orbits during a period when giant planet orbits were changing. Therefore, studying them tells us about the earliest periods of Solar System history and helps us understand planetary systems around other stars.

 

We measured the colors of the target objects as a means of estimating their compositions and comparing them to asteroids and comets elsewhere in the Solar System. There has been an open question as to whether the colors of smaller objects would be the same as for the larger objects. If the distribution of colors is different for smaller objects, it would suggest that some process like micrometeorite impacts or irradiation by UV light changes Trojan asteroid surfaces with time. If the distribution is the same regardless of size, it would suggest that such processes aren't important. As a result, we tried to observe many small targets, which were unobserved prior to our efforts. Understanding the ways Trojan asteroid surfaces change will help us understand how much of what we see is directly showing surface composition vs. how much additional work and assumptions we need to make to identify those compositions.

 

A preliminary analysis of the observations we took is more consistent with the second case. We find that the distribution of colors of small Trojan asteroids is similar to the distribution for larger objects. However, an analysis of a second dataset, taken as part of an all-sky astrophysical survey, is more ambiguous. We will continue work under other funding to understand how these two datasets differ and agree. 

 

Beyond science, this project was able to involve students from all over the world. Colleagues (faculty and postdocs) in South Africa were heavily involved in data collection and reduction, and this led to a proposal to the South African National Research Foundation to establish a planetary science program in Cape Town, which would be the first-ever in Africa. While that proposal was not selected, we expect to make another attempt. The data was also used at the Vatican Observatory Summer School in Italy in a research project for eight graduate students (Annabella Mondino of Universidad de Cordoba [Argentina], Chuhong Mai of ASU, Leos Pohl of U Central Florida, Andreita Correa of Escuela Politecnica Nacional [Ecuador], Khemsinan Gunsriwiwat of Chiang Mai University [Thailand], Anthony Frushour of the Univeristy of Indiana, Joseph Serigano of Johns Hopkins, and Paolo Madonia of the University of Palermo [Italy]). PI Rivkin mentored them for four weeks,  introducing them to asteroid science and the technique and issues of photometry on moving targets.
